items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. Today is forecast to be mainly dry but more rain is forecast tomorrow morning, 29/10/21. 
We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: Water levels remain steady but high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck, Derwentwater and surrounding watercourses as a result of persistent heavy rain. Flooding is likely to affect low-lying land in locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwentwater. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near these watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We are monitoring the situation and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated tomorrow 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Ehen, Calder, Irt and Esk

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ehen, Rive Calder, River Irt, River Esk

items.message: River levels remain steady but high at the Egremont river gauge as a result of the persistent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Ennerdale Bridge, Cleator Moor, Cleator, Egremont, Beckermet, Braystones, Calder Bridge, Holmrook and Bootle areas. High river levels remain possible on the River Wyre, Distington Beck, Pow Beck, River Ehen, River Keekle, Skirting Beck, Whangs Beck, Kirk Beck, River Calder, River Irt, River Esk, River Annas and their tributaries. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking and clearing debris screens. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded, and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow 29/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Greta, St Johns Beck and Bassenthwaite Lake

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Greta, St Johns Beck, Glendermackin

items.message: River levels will remain high at the Keswick Camp Site river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible. The areas we expect to be affected are the Mungrisdale, Threlkeld, Keswick, Portinscale, Braithwaite, Bassenthwaite and Wythop Mill areas. River and lake levels will remain high on the River Glenderamackin, St Johns Beck, River Greta, Naddle Beck, Cuddy Beck, River Derwent, Newlands Beck, Coledale Beck, Bassenthwaite Lake, Halls Beck, Chapel Beck, Wythop Beck and their tributaries. With rainfall easing overnight tonight (28/10/21) levels will remain steady but high throughout Friday and into the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow 29/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck

items.message: River levels remain steady but high at the Egremont river gauge as a result of the persistent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Ennerdale Bridge, Cleator Moor, Cleator, Egremont, Beckermet, Braystones, Calder Bridge, Holmrook and Bootle areas. High river levels remain on the River Wyre, Distington Beck, Pow Beck, River Ehen, River Keekle, Skirting Beck, Whangs Beck, Kirk Beck, River Calder, River Irt, River Esk, River Annas and their tributaries. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking and clearing debris screens. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded, and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow 29/10/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain stable but high on the Rivers Wampool and Ellen due to the heavy rainfall. Flooding will continue to affect locations near the Rivers Wampool and Ellen, with low lying land expected to be most affected. Other watercourses from Dalston to Maryport also remain affected (including low lying areas around Wigton, Abbeytown, Silloth, Allonby, Aspatria and Dearham). We will continue to monitor levels closely and our staff are out clearing blockages. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cocker, River Marron, River Derwent

items.message: River levels will remain high and steady on the Rivers Cocker, Marron and Derwent due to the persistent rainfall. Consequently, flooding to low lying land and roads remain. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Buttermere, Lorton Valley, Cockermouth, Branthwaite, Bridgefoot, Camerton, Barepot and Workington areas. High river levels will remain on the River Cocker, Whit Beck, River Derwent, River Marron, Lostrigg Beck and their tributaries. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Mint Bridge and Victoria Bridge river gauges as a result of recent rainfall. With rainfall easing overnight tonight (28/10/21), river levels are expected to remain steady but high until tomorrow (29/10/21). Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Staveley, Ings, Burneside, Kendal, Garnett Bridge, Stainton, Sedgwick, Holme, Beetham and Milnthorpe areas. High river levels are possible on the Rivers Kent, Gowan, Sprint, Mint, Stock Beck, Stainton Beck, Peasey Beck, Farleton Beck, River Bela, Holme Beck and their tributaries. We are closely monitoring the situation and our teams are out checking defences and debris screens. This message will be updated tomorrow 29/10/21 or as the situation changes.

River levels remain stable but high on the Rivers Esk and Irthing due to the persistent rainfall. Flooding will continue to affect locations near the Rivers Esk and Irthing, with low lying land expected to be most affected, including low lying areas around Longtown and Brampton. We are clearing debris from screens in the area and will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain stable but high on the Rivers Lowther and Eamont due to persistent heavy rainfall. Flooding will continue to affect locations near the Rivers Lowther and Eamont, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Rivers Eamont and Lowther to their confluence with the River Eden at Langwathby. We are monitoring the situation and our staff have been checking defences and unblocking debris screens where needed. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message: Water levels remain high on Lake Windermere, Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, particularly from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands which includes low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel due to the recent persistent rainfall. With rainfall easing overnight tonight (28/10/21) levels will remain steady but high. We are monitoring the situation and our staff have been checking defences and unblocking debris screens where needed. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow, 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Rothay at Grasmere, White Bridge and Stock Lane
items.message: River levels remain high due to persistent heavy rainfall and is forecast to continue over the next few days. Areas most at risk include River Rothay at Grasmere, White Bridge, Church Stile, Stock Lane and Lake View Drive areas. We expect river levels remain high. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your surroundings. This message will be updated 16:00 today 28/10/2021 or as the situation changes.

The level of Derwent Water will remain high following recent heavy rainfall. Whilst rainfall is expected to ease overnight, the following areas will remain at risk of flooding. These include low lying land bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site. Avoid using low lying roads and footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This Flood Warning is expected to remain in place for several days as the levels will remain high. We will continue to monitor the forecast and update this message tomorrow 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain stable but high at the Linstock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Crosby-on-Eden, Linstock, Carlisle and Rockcliffe areas. High river levels remain on the River Eden, River Caldew, River Petteril, Durranhill Beck, Brunstock Beck, Gosling Sike, Little Caldew, Parham Beck, Rockcliffe Beck and their tributaries. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are checking rivers for blockages. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near rivers and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Greta at Keswick, Keswick Campsite, Rugby Club and Quinta
items.message: River levels remain high at the Keswick Camp Site river gauge as a result of recent persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected. Flooding is expected to affect low lying roads, residential, commercial properties and campsites in Keswick adjacent to the Rivers Greta and Derwent. Including Greta Park Rugby Football Ground, Keswick Campsite, Keswick School Sports Field, Keswick Show Field and Playing Field areas. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 16:00 today 28/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Kent at Burneside, Steeles Row and Carling Steps
items.message: River levels remain high on the River Kent due to heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk include residential properties immediately adjacent the River Kent in Bridge Street, Steeles Row, Junction Cottages and Carling Steps areas of Burneside Village. Flooding is possible between 08:30 PM 27/10/2021 and 07:00 PM on 28/10/2021. Further rainfall is forecast for the next few days. River levels are expected to remain high. Our incident rooms are open and we are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 16:00 today 28/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high on the River Lune due to heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible for the next few days. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Lune, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around River Lune, Rawthey and other watercourses from Tebay to Kirkby Lonsdale including Sedburgh and Killington. High river levels are likely on the River Lune, Rawthey and other watercourses from Tebay to Kirkby Lonsdale including Sedburgh and Killington. Further rainfall is forecast until Friday 29/10/2021. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high on the River Lune and River Conder due to rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible for the next few days. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Lune; River Conder, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around River Lune, Conder and Keer and other watercourses from Kirkby Lonsdale to Galgate including Gressingham, Carnforth, Hornby, Wray, Bentham and Lancaster. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow 29/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

The flood alert for the Upper River Ure is no longer in force. River levels on the Upper Ure did not rise to levels predicted because rainfall totals came in below the level forecast on Wednesday evening. Further rainfall is expected throughout today, Thursday 28th October, which may see river levels rise again. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast and will re-issue the flood alert if it is required. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Swale, Gilling Beck, Skeeby Beck

items.message: The flood alert for the Upper River Swale is no longer in force. River levels on the Upper Swale did not rise to levels predicted because rainfall totals came in below the level forecast on Wednesday evening. Further rainfall is expected throughout today, Thursday 28th October, which may see river levels rise again. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast and will re-issue the flood alert if it is required. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: River Ehen at Egremont, Bleach Green, Ennerdale Mill, Bridge End, Vale View, Wood Bank, Rugby Club
items.message: River levels remain high on the River Ehen due to recent persistent heavy rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ehen, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around properties adjacent to the River Ehen at Egremont, including the Bleach Green, Ennerdale Mill, Bridge End, Vale View, Wood Bank and Rugby Club areas. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. River levels are expected to remain high and the River Ehen is expected to peak around 13:00 PM. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 16:00 today 28/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

Whilst river levels have peaked and rainfall has eased, river levels on the River Cocker remain high due to recent persistent rainfall. High river levels will continue to affect locations near the River Cocker, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around farms and property adjacent the River Cocker in the Lorton Valley, Southwaite Bridge and Southwaite Mill. Avoid using low lying roads and footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We will continue to monitor the forecast and update this message tomorrow 29/10/2021.

items.description: Rivers Cocker and Derwent at Cockermouth, Cricket Ground and Trout Hotel Car Park
items.message: River levels remain high on the Rivers Cocker and Derwent due to recent persistent heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk include commercial and residential properties adjacent to the Rivers Cocker and Derwent at Cockermouth, in the Brewery Lane, Bridge Street, Crown Street, High Sand Lane, Main Street and Waterloo Street areas. Flooding is expected from 01:00 AM on 28/10/2021. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We expect river levels to remain high. We have closed the flood gates in the area and will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary. Consider putting your flood plan into action. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 16:00 on the 28/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Rothay at Grasmere, Broadgate, College Street and Town End
Dragley Beck at Ulverston from Dragley Beck Bridge on Well Lane downstream to South Ulverston

items.message:
River levels are high and forecast to rise further on the River Ehen due to heavy rainfall.
Areas most at risk include properties adjacent to the River Ehen at Low Mill with flooding forecast from 10:00 AM on 28/10/2021.
Further rainfall is forecast this morning. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.
This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 28/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Derwent at Workington, Seaton Mill and Barepot
items.message:
River levels are high and forecast to rise further on the River Derwent due to heavy rainfall.
Areas most at risk include residential and commercial properties at Seaton Mill, Barepot, Hall Park, Hall Park View, Workington Police Station, Leisure Centre, Bowling Green and Cricket Club. Flooding is possible from 11:30 AM on 28/10/2021. Further rainfall is forecast this morning but river levels are expected to start to fall slowly from early this afternoon. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.
This message will be updated by 06:00 PM on 28/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Leven at Newby Bridge and Backbarrow
items.message:
River levels are high and forecast to rise further on the River Leven due to heavy rainfall.
Flooding is expected at properties adjacent to the River Leven at Newby Bridge and Backbarrow, including the Swan Hotel, Boat Houses, Mill Farm, The Whitewater Hotel, Water Close, Lakeland Village, Coach House and Levens Dale from 02:00 PM on 28/10/2021. Further heavy rainfall is forecast to continue until around 2:00 PM today 28/10/2021, this will be followed by more intermittent showers over the next few days. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.
This message will be updated by 08:00 PM on 28/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high and forecast to rise further on Windermere due to heavy rainfall.
Flooding is expected at low lying commercial and residential properties, camping, caravan sites and leisure facilities on the shores of Windermere from 04:00 PM on 28/10/2021. Further light rainfall is forecast this afternoon and lake levels are expected to rise steadily at the Far Sawrey gauge. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. 
This message will be updated by 09:00 PM on 28/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Upper Tean river gauge as a result of expected heavy rainfall this evening.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected overnight into tomorrow, Thursday 28/10/21 to Friday 29/10/21.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Churnet between Leek and Rocester and the River Tean between Adderley and Spath including Cecilly Brook at Cheadle.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 72 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Friday 29/10/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Marchington Brook, Picknall Brook, Rolleston Brook

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Uttoxeter river gauge as a result of expected heavy rainfall this evening.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected overnight into tomorrow, Thursday 28/10/21 to Friday 29/10/21.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the Picknall Brook, Marchington Brook and Rolleston Brook.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 72 hours.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Friday 29/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible overnight Thursday and in to Friday morning.

Heavy rain is forecast to fall in the Rivers Clyst and Culm area until Friday morning. This will cause water levels in the Rivers Clyst, Culm and their tributaries to rise. 

Flooding is possible to low lying land and roads close to the rivers from Thursday evening. 

We expect the rivers to remain high throughout Friday though no flooding to properties is forecast and warnings are not currently expected to be issued.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 

We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible on Thursday evening and overnight into Friday morning.
Heavy rainfall is forecast to fall in the River Dart area until early Friday morning. This will cause water levels in the River Dart to rise. 
Bankfull conditions are expected with some localised riverside field flooding from 8:30pm on Thursday. 
We expect the river to remain high throughout Friday with further rainfall expected from Friday evening.  
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Plym, Tory Brook, Long Brook

items.message:
Flooding is possible this evening, Thursday 28th October, and into Friday due to persistent and heavy rainfall crossing the area. Following unsettled weather over the past week, catchments are saturated and rivers are likely to respond quickly to the forecast rainfall.
Widespread rainfall totals of 20-30 mm are expected. Intense rain may result in totals of up 50 mm, increasing to 70mm over high ground. This may result in deep surface water and flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers from around 8pm on Thursday. Flood warnings may be issued for some locations.
The most persistent rain is expected to ease during Friday before further outbreaks of rain spread in from the west during the evening and into Saturday. River levels are likely to remain high during this time.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area ready to clear blockages as required. This message will be updated on Friday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

River levels are still rising on the River Tweed at the Norham gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall today, 28/10/21. Consequently, flooding of riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads between Carham to Union Bridge is possible this evening and into the early hours of Friday morning (29/10/21) when river levels are expected to peak. 

We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 29/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Coly, River Yarty, Umborne Brook

items.message:
Flooding is possible on Thursday evening and overnight into Friday morning. 
Heavy rainfall is forecast to fall over mid and east Devon until early Friday morning.
The River Axe, River Coly, Umborne Brook and River Yarty are likely to rise to bankfull conditions with some localised riverside flooding.   
Further rain is forecast from Friday evening into Saturday morning. This will cause river levels to rise again with further flooding expected in the area.  
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on Friday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Teign, River Bovey, River Lemon, River Kenn

items.message:
Flooding is possible on Thursday evening and overnight into Friday morning.
Heavy rainfall is forecast to fall in the River Teign area until early Friday morning. This will cause water levels in the River Teign and its tributaries to rise. 
Bankfull conditions are expected with some localised riverside field flooding from 6:45pm on Thursday. 
We expect the rivers to remain high throughout Friday with further rainfall expected from Friday evening.  
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes

items.description: Rivers Otter and Sid, and Exmouth area
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible on Thursday evening and overnight into Friday morning. 
Heavy rainfall is forecast to fall over mid and east Devon until early Friday morning. 
This has meant that the River Otter, the River Sid, and rivers in the Exmouth area are now rising. River levels will remain high and flooding to low lying land and roads is likely.   
Further rain is forecast from Friday evening into Saturday morning. This will cause river levels to rise again with further flooding expected in the area.  
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on Friday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible overnight on Thursday and into Friday morning.
Heavy rainfall is forecast to fall in the River Torridge area until early Friday morning. This has meant that the River Torridge is now rising. 
Levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land including car parking areas and roads close to the river from around 3:30am on Friday morning. Residents may need to install flood boards to prevent wash generated from cars from entering properties.  
Further rain is forecast overnight on Friday. This will cause river levels to rise again with further flooding expected in the area.  
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Lyd, River Thrushel

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Exe, River Batherm, River Lowman, River Haddeo

items.message:
Flooding is possible overnight Thursday and in to Friday morning.

Heavy rain is forecast to fall in the River Exe area until Friday morning. This will cause water levels in the Rivers Exe, Haddeo, Batherm and Lowman to rise. 

The main area of concern is at Bampton, where levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river and around the bridge from the early hours of Friday morning. 

We expect rivers to remain high throughout Friday though no flooding to properties is forecast and warnings are not currently expected to be issued.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 

We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Avon, River Erme, River Harbourne

items.message:
Flooding is possible on Thursday evening and overnight into Friday morning.

Heavy rainfall is forecast to fall in the South Devon Rivers area until early Friday morning. This will cause water levels in the Rivers Harbourne, Avon and Erme to rise.

Bankfull conditions are expected with some localised riverside field flooding around Crowdy Mill from 2am on Friday.

We expect the rivers to remain high throughout Friday with further rainfall expected from Friday evening. 

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.

We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Camel, River Allen, Bodmin Town Leat, River Valency

items.message:
Flooding is possible this evening, Thursday 28th October, and into Friday due to persistent and heavy rainfall crossing the area. Following unsettled weather over the past week, catchments are saturated and rivers are likely to respond quickly to the forecast rainfall.
Widespread rainfall totals of 20-30 mm are expected. Intense rain may result in totals of up 50 mm, increasing to 70mm over high ground. Urban areas may respond the quickest to this rainfall. Deep surface water and flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers is expected from around 8pm on Thursday. Flood warnings may be issued for some locations.
The most persistent rain is expected to ease during Friday before further outbreaks of rain spread in from the west during the evening and into Saturday. River levels are likely to remain high during this time.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area ready to clear blockages as required. This message will be updated on Friday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Ullswater and River Eamont at Pooley Bridge, Ullswater Steamer Pier to B5320 Bridge
items.message:
River and Lake levels have risen at the Pooley Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding is possible.  Flooding is expected to affect properties on the B5320 between Dunmallard Hill and the River Eamont, including the Steamer Pier.   
We expect levels to peak this evening (28/10/21) and levels to remain high into tomorrow.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying roads and footpaths near rivers.  
This message will be updated tomorrow (29/10/21), or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible this evening, Thursday 28th October, and into Friday due to persistent and heavy rainfall crossing the area. Following unsettled weather over the past week, catchments are saturated and rivers are responding quickly to the forecast rainfall.
Widespread rainfall totals of 20-30 mm are expected. Intense rain could result in totals of up to 50 mm, increasing to 70 mm over high ground. This may cause flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers. Flood warnings may be issued for some locations.
The most persistent rain is expected to ease during Friday before further outbreaks of rain spread in from the west during the evening and into Saturday. River levels are likely to remain high during this time.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area ready to respond as required. This message will be updated on Friday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible early on Friday morning. 
Heavy rainfall is falling over north Devon. This has meant that the rivers in the North Dartmoor area are now rising and there will be bankfull conditions with some localised riverside field flooding from around 8am.   
Further rain is forecast from Friday evening into Saturday morning. This will cause river levels to rise again with further flooding expected in the area.  
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on Friday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible from 5am on Friday morning onwards.

Further rainfall is forecast to fall in the Lower Taw area which will cause water levels in the River Umberleigh to rise.

Bankfull conditions are expected with some localised riverside field flooding.

Further rainfall is expected from Friday evening into Saturday morning. 

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.

We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Barle, River Exe, River Lyn, River Mole, River Bray

items.message:
Flooding is possible overnight Thursday in to Friday.

Over the last 12 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the Exmoor Rivers area. This has meant that the Rivers Barle, Lyn, Mole, Bray and upper River Exe are now rising. 

The main areas of concern are Simonsbath, Brushford, Withypool and Dulverton, where levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river from around 8:00pm on Thursday. 

We expect rivers to remain high throughout the night in to Friday though no flooding to properties is forecast and warnings are not currently expected to be issued.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 

We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Friday evening or earlier if the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Calder, Walsden Water, Hebden Water

items.message:
The River Calder is forecast to rise as a result of heavy rainfall from late 28/10/21 to early 29/10/21.  River levels are expected to peak several times on 29/10/2021: between midnight and 08:00am at Walsden; and 04:00am and 11:15am at Elland.
The latest forecast indicates the possibility of flooding in the upper river around Walsden but as this part of the river is on the eastern edge of the main band of rain moving north, there is significant uncertainty around any impacts.

We are closely monitoring the forecast as it changes and our incident response staff have been out checking defences. 

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and be aware rivers could rise very quickly even if it's not raining where you are.  

This message will be updated at 8:00am 29/10/21 or as the situation changes.

The flood alert for Upper River Wharfe has been issued as river levels are forecast to rise at Netherside Hall due to heavy rainfall on Thursday 28th and Friday 29th October. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected from the early hours of Friday morning. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Further rain is forecast during Friday morning and over the weekend. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Friday 29th October, or as the situation changes. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

River levels are rising at the Donyatt and Ashford Mill river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible tonight, 28/10/21, and tomorrow, 29/10/21.  We expect flooding to affect roads at Ashford Mill, Isle Brewers, Fivehead, the Norton sub Hambdon to Stratton road, the A356 and the B3165 at Chiselborough and the B3168 at Ilford Bridges. The lower River Parrett is forecast to be bankfull and overtopping could occur.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high throughout the weekend.  We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  This message will be updated by 13:00 on Friday, 29/10/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Hillfarrance Brook, Halsewater Stream, River Tone

items.message: River levels are rising at the Bishops Hull river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible tonight, 28/10/21 and tomorrow, 29/10/21.  We expect flooding to affect roads around Hillfarrance, Bradford on Tone, Lane End Road at Ham and the Creech St Michael to Henlade road. Bradford on Tone ringbanks will be bankfull.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high throughout the weekend.  We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens.  Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  This message will be updated by 13:00 on Friday, 29/10/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message: River levels are rising at the Beggearn Huish river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible tonight, 28/10/21 and tomorrow, 29/10/21.  We expect flooding to affect the Horner Water, Rivers Aller and Washford, and the Hawkcombe, Monksilver and Doniford Streams and tributaries.  Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high throughout the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Friday, 29/10/21, or as the situation changes.

The flood alert for the River Rye Catchment has been issued as river levels are forecast to rise on the River Rye and its tributaries due to heavy rainfall on Thursday 28th and Friday 29th October. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected from the early hours of Friday morning. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Further rain is forecast during Friday morning and over the weekend. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Friday 29th October, or as the situation changes. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: River Tavy from Mary Tavy to Lopwell
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected during Thursday night and Friday morning. Take immediate action.
Heavy rain has fallen over the Tavy catchment with a further 20 mm of rain expected. This has caused the River Tavy to rise and the river is forecast to continue rising over the next 2-3 hours.
Properties and low lying areas around Stannary Bridge Road, Parkwood Road, Market Road, Dolvin Road, Abbey Walk, Pixon Lane at Tavistock will start to flood first from around 21:30 on Thursday. River levels are forecast to be at their highest around midnight and could remain high for several hours afterwards.
Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing, and roads could form flow routes. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 10am on Friday or earlier if the situation changes. Our staff are out in the area and will relay information and assist the emergency services and council.
